授業目的: This course aims at making graduate students fully knowledgeable of systematic analysis and professional understanding of diplomacy, peace and security including the United Nations, focusing on key issues in the context of broad historical and political trends. Such approach is particularly needed in Japan, where the predominant tendency in diplomatic studies has been theoretical, legalistic, or idealistic rather than pragmatic.
到達目標:
1. Students will be able to develop their own intellectual and professional capacity to evaluate.
2. Students will be able to discuss the significance of diplomatic policies, activities, and issues in relation to the international trends and forces at work.
特記事項: 【合併】Seminar in Diplomacy, Peace and Security　（大学院共通科目・認定科目前期）/外交・平和・安全保障演習　（司法研究科）/Seminar in Diplomacy, Peace and Security　（経営戦略研究科）
授業方法: Please note that the classes are face to face in principle unless otherwise instructed by the instructors. However, pending the situation classes may be done on-line basis. Course Format is Seminar style. Students are required to actively participate in the discussions and asked to make presentation on the designated topics.

第1回:
April 10, Session 1: Introduction (global situation of the world politics and geopolitical risks) (Shinyo)

2024 is the year of election in many parts of the world, US, Russia, India, and Taiwan.  Russia has still no way to win in Ukraine. The European Union is stronger than ever with occasional disunity. NATO rediscovered its reason for being Guardian in geopolitical confrontations. The G7 is strengthening its solidarity. American hard power remains unrivaled but shaky because of the presidential elections. Dictatorships are stumbling while they’re becoming more consolidated. Vladimir Putin’s Russia is isolated for its leader to attend the G20 summit, facing serious economic and military decline ... while NATO has never looked stronger. Iran, Russia’s most important military ally, faces a deeply hostile geopolitical environment alongside the greatest domestic unrest since the 1979 revolution that brought the Islamic Republic to power. China was thoroughly unprepared for its socio-economic troubles with zero Covid, leading to unprecedented demonstrations ... and a sudden turnaround of President Xi Jinping’s policy. Their trajectories are, to varying degrees, increasingly unsustainable.

The Eurasia Group, led by political analyst Mr. Ian Bremmer has been issuing for years a geopolitical risk report at the beginning of the year, which is known as EURASIA GROUP'S TOP RISKS for the year. Ten top risks of the year will be introduced as a forecast with some “Red Herrings”.
This introductory session will look the 2024 report and discuss the relevance of the analysis with critical thinking.

April 17, Session 2:  China, U.S. and the New World Order (Shinyo)

With the rise of China as a great power and the reclining tendency of the US dominance as the sole superpower, particularly with former President Trump’s inward-looking attitude of "America First policy", the world order is embarking on a new stage. Whether President Biden's new policy towards China will change the course yet remains to be seen.

The trade and cyber/high-tech war between the two superpowers could cause serious tension and crisis, which could be interpreted as a wrong drawing of the lessons of the so-called “Thucydides Trap”.

This session will examine how the US and China see the future world and their relations with each other followed by discussions with the instructor or among students.

Students must read the articles to be provided by the instructor in advance and prepare for the class.

April 24, Session 3: Shifting Global Order and Multilateral Frameworks for Economic Security Legislations (Shinyo with guest speaker Dr. Yukari Sato)

Amidst the US endeavor to reestablish the international economic order vis a vis China’s rise, the Statement of the G7 Hiroshima Summit (2023) came just in time. The Statement refers to the coordination of economic resilience and economic security that is based on diversifying and deepening partnerships and de-risking (but not de-coupling), reiterating the importance of FOIP (Free and Open Indo-Pacific Strategy). At the same time, we see the IPEF (Indo-Pacific Economic Framework) proceeding and high-level negotiations are underway based on the conclusion of the IPEF Supply Chain Agreement (May 2023). We will discuss the effectiveness and power of enforcement of these multilateral negotiations, and the latest legislative move of each country concerned.

May 1, Session4:  Comparative study on Diplomacy, Peace and Security; a case of Europe

(Shinyo with guest speaker)

We will be hearing views from an Expert, tentatively from Germany or the EU.

We will be learning German or EU foreign and security policy for Europe and Asia, particularly the historic change of its military posture because of the Ukrainian War. Comparison with Japan also makes sense, because Japan sifted its security and military policy to an unprecedented level as well based on a new threat perception caused by its neighbors. We will further learn what is the role of Europe and Japan in a multipolar world, including how to cope with authoritarian regimes, such as China and Russia, while nurturing multilateralism and reinforcing liberal world order.

第7回:
May 22: Session 7: Towards “East Asia community” and its feasibility in a changing world order (Shinyo)

The concept of an "East Asia community" was proposed in the past by two Japanese Prime Ministers, namely Junichiro Koizumi in 2002 and Yukio Hatoyama in 2009 both in Singapore.

A part of this concept was realized as the "East Asia Summit” in 2005, held each year in one of the capitals of the eighteen participating countries, including China, the US, Russia and Japan. The base of this Summit was AEEAN +3(Japan, China and Korea).

In the changing context of world order in the Asia-Pacific will it be possible to develop an idea of a greater regional political framework to maintain peace and stability and expand networking and connectivity as represented by ASEAN countries to the entire Asia and Pacific region? Is such a regionalism, which could be called an “Entente”, conducive to enhancing cooperative relations among nations? If so, what must be done to develop this idea, and if not, what else countries must do to avoid confrontation and conflicts?

 Reading materials: to be provided by the instructor.

However, students are expected to read articles or books through the internet or publications.

May 29, Session 8: On Climate Change and Security Risks（１）

(Shinyo with Guest Speaker Prof. Horie)

 Climate Change is a significant threat to the national security of many countries in the world. Already in 2010, the US Department of Defense designated climate change as a crucial factor to consider in future national security planning. The situation of climate change has been deteriorating rapidly as much as naming it “Climate Emergency”.

In developing countries, climate change aggravates livelihood insecurity caused by desertification or natural disasters, and competition for scarce food and water which lead to armed conflicts between different ethnic groups or civil wars.

In this class, we consider why climate change poses serious security risks to developing and developed countries and how the world is trying to mitigate the impact.

June 12, Session 10: The issue of the History of Japan and Its Political Implications on Japanese Foreign Affairs; Is Reconciliation with Neighboring Countries Possible? (Shinyo)

The issues of comfort women or the wartime workers from the Korean Peninsula in the Second World War have become one of the top agenda and tremendous obstacles to the bilateral relations between South Korea and Japan. Even after the Treaty on Basic Relations between Japan and the Republic of Korea and the bilateral agreement on settling the claims and compensation in 1965 as well as the agreement on comfort women, recently, in 2016, why Korea is still blaming Japan and asking for compensation and apology from Japan? What are the issues and what kind of diplomatic efforts have been made between the two countries? We will be examining this issue from the diplomatic point of view and thinking about what must be done to mitigate the tension if not entirely solve the question.

June 19, Session 11: The Future of Asian Century (Shinyo)

Asian countries see the United States as a resident power that has vital interests in the region. At the same time, China is a reality on the doorstep. Asian countries do not want to be forced to choose between the two. And if either attempts to force such a choice—if Washington tries to contain China’s rise or Beijing seeks to build an exclusive sphere of influence in Asia—they will begin a course of confrontation that will last decades and put the long-heralded Asian century in jeopardy. The United States and China are not the only major countries with a great deal of influence in the region; other players also have significant roles　such as Japan, India, and ASEAN.

We will examine how the South-East Asian countries see the future of Asia.

Reference material: Lee Hsien Loong, "The Endangered Asian Century- America, China, and the Perils of Confrontation" Foreign Affairs, JULY/AUGUST 2020

July 3, Session 13: Security policy of Japan (comparison between Japan and Germany in the case of collective security and collective self-defense against the backdrop of the constraints in their respective constitutions) (Shinyo)

Since the end of the Cold War in 1989, Japan and Germany both the defeated countries in the World War II embarked on a new stage to proactively contribute to the maintenance of the world peace by military and non-military means at their disposal. However, there are constitutional constraints in both countries, when they dispatch military forces beyond their territory for the UN Peace Operations including UNPKO and other military activities to maintain peace. Particularly in case of Japan, the issue of the right to collective self-defense has always been argued in connection to the dispatch of the Self-Defence Forces outside Japan. How Japan and Germany have tried to overcome this sensitive political issue in recent years will be clarified
in parallel comparison.

Reading materials:
Takahiro Shinyo, “Germany’s Constitutional View and Security, -Study of Basic Law for the Federal Republic of Germany and Bundeswehr’s Overseas Dispatch”. The Journal of the Governance Institute, 2017 Winter pp.54-71

第14回:
July 10, Session14: Nuclear Disarmament and the United Nations (Shinyo with guest)

UN Secretary-General calls for resuming dialogue and negotiations for nuclear arms control and disarmament. He also supports extending the norms against nuclear weapons, and in that regard appeals to States that possess nuclear weapons to affirm that a nuclear war cannot be won and must never be fought. Finally, he proposes preparing for a world free of nuclear weapons through a number of risk -reduction measures, including transparency in nuclear-weapon programmes, further reductions in all types of nuclear weapons, commitments not to introduce new and destabilizing types of nuclear weapons, including cruise missiles, reciprocal commitments for the non-use of nuclear weapons and reduction of the role of nuclear weapons in security doctrines. We will discuss how international community, particularly the nuclear weapon states, can embark on a new stage of nuclear disarmament and what role should the United Nations and its member states, including Japan, play to promote this extraordinarily difficult political task. We will also discuss pros and cons to the Treaty on the Prohibition of nuclear weapons (TPNW), which entered into force on 22 January 2021.
